channel.title: install on IT Talks
channel.description: Recent content in install on IT Talks

item.title: Git Clone via SSH using Jenkins on Windows
item.description:
The cleanest way to use Jenkins on Windows is to use the Jenkins Installer which installs Jenkins as a Windows Service.

That works fine, but of course the first challenge you face is cloning your Git repo over SSH (the default for the Jenkins Git plugin).

item.title: How to install Maven on CentOS
item.description:
Apache Maven is a project management software, managing building, reporting and documentation of a Java  development project. In order to install and configure Apache Maven on CentOS, follow these steps.

First of all, you need to install Java 1.8 JDK. Make sure to install Java JDK, not JRE.

Then go ahead and download the latest Maven binary from its official site. For example, for version 3.3.9:

item.title: Monitor Logs in Real-Time with “Log.io” on CentOS 6/7
item.description:
Log.io is a small simple but effective application build on top of Node.js and Socket.io, which allows to monitor Linux servers log files in real time through web interface screen widgets.

How to install and configure log.io:

item.title: Installing workstation for managing Chef server
item.description:
A workstation is a computer that is configured to run knife, to synchronize with the chef-repo, and interact with a single Chef server. The workstation is the location from which most users will do most of their work.

We need ti install on our workstation:

  • knife
  • chef-sdk
  • chef-repo
  • ruby

item.title: Installing Chef on Centos 6
item.description:
Today we will install chef server in our home lab based on proxmox 3.4.6. So we have installed server 2cpu, 2Gb memory, Centos 6.7

First of all I switched off selinux, and configured hostname of server in /etc/sysconfig/network and /etc/hosts

Let’s go on:

#wget https://web-dl.packagecloud.io/chef/stable/packages/el/6/chef-server-core-12.1.2-1.el6.x86_64.rpm

# rpm -Uvh chef-server-core-12.1.2-1.el6.x86_64.rpm

item.title: “Cannot run upgrade script on host” during upgrade from esxi 5.5 to 6.0
item.description: The host upgrade from ESXi 5.5 to ESXi 6.0 failed with the following error: „Cannot execute upgrade script on host“.

item.title: The data service timed out because a back-end task took more than 120
item.description:
Today I received error on my vm summary page in Vsphere web client: The data service timed out because a back-end task took more than 120 seconds. See the vsphere-client-virgo.log for more details.

Just before that I removed a test vcenter server, which was connected to my PSC  on production Vsphere instance.

You need to remove a stale vCenter Server from your SSO environment, use the cmsso-util. It may takes a long time but does the job.

item.title: Cooking with Chef: How to deploy instance on AWS with knife
item.description:
Today I want to try provisioning and configuring Amazon AWS instances with Chef. To do that I have:

  • Free tier account on AWS
  • Open Source Chef Server 12
  • Ubuntu Workstation with knife

item.title: Can’t upgrade esxi 5.5 to 6.0 due a vib conflict
item.description:
Today I tried to upgrade my standalone (not in Cluster) host (HP DL 180 G6) with esxi 6.0 and Update Manager. But when the process starts I had received this error:

The upgrade contains the following set of cpnflicting VIBs:

Mellanox_bootbank_net-mlx4-en_1.9.9.0-1OEM.550.0.0.1331820
